paper_title: Enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction in H2O vapor by atomically thin Bi2WO6 nanosheets with hydrophobic and nonpolar surface

catalyst.source: For all this, for the first time, Bi 2 WO 6 photocatalysts with atomically thin structure along with hydrophobic and nonpolar surface are successfully designed and prepared using CTAB as assistant.
catalyst.context: The artificial carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) photoreduction into useful chemicals utilizing solar energy demands the stable photocatalysts with high-efficiency charge separation and effective CO 2 adsorption capacity.For all this, for the first time, Bi 2 WO 6 photocatalysts with atomically thin structure along with hydrophobic and nonpolar surface are successfully designed and prepared using CTAB as assistant.The ultrathin feature with short diffusion distance significantly facilitates the charge separation.The hydrophobic surface, modified by nonpolar long carbon chains of CTA , boosts both the mass-transfer and adsorption of CO 2 , meanwhile suppressing the H 2 O adsorption.Hence, the prepared photocatalyst exhibits a high-efficiency photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 in H 2 O vapor without co-catalyst due to high CO 2 concentration and sufficient photogenerated carriers.The photocatalytic mechanisms including adsorption concentration and activation process of CO 2 are further revealed by the in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS).As a new feature, linearly adsorbed CO at 2035 cm -1 is found on hydrophobic surface of Bi 2 WO 6 , and the absorbance of CO is critical to the next reaction step for CH 4 generation.This innovation provides a facile avenue for the design of photocatalysts with remarkable CO 2 capture ability to achieve the practical application of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.However, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is the competing

catalyst.source: In summary, atomically thin Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets with hydrophobic surface have been fabricated via a one-step hydrothermal method for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.
catalyst.context: In summary, atomically thin Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets with hydrophobic surface have been fabricated via a one-step hydrothermal method for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.The atomically thin nanosheet improves the charge separation in Bi 2 WO 6 due to the short diffusion distance from interior to surface.The hydrophobic surface caused by nonpolar long carbon chains of CTAB enhances CO 2 adsorption onto the nonpolar surface, leading to the high concentration of CO 2 on surface for CO 2 photoreduction.Furthermore, the CO adsorption on the hydrophobic surface is favorable for the photo-methanation reaction to form CH 4 .Therefore, the atomically thin Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets with hydrophobic surface display a high-efficiency photocatalytic CO 2 reduction in H 2 O vapor.This study provides an appealing method for the design of highly efficient photocatalyst for solar energy conversion. light source.source: The light source was 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-HXF300, Au-Light, China) equipped with AM 1.5.
light source.context: The chemicals using in this work including Bismuth nitrate pentahydrate (Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O, 99.0 ), Sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O, 99.5 ), Hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB, 99 ), and Potassium bromide (KBr, 99.5 ) were purchased from Aladdin and used without further purification.High purity CO 2 (99.999 ) was provided by Air Liquide China. 13C labelled CO 2 gas (99 atom 13 C) were purchased from Wuhan Newradar Special Gas Company Limited. 1 mmol of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O, 0.5 mmol of Na 2 WO 4 2H 2 O and 0.025-0.08g of CTAB were added to 70 mL of deionized water with ultrasonic for 10 min.After stirring for 30 min, the above mixed solution was transferred into the Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 120 C for 24 h.The as-prepared sample was collected by filtration and washed with deionized water for several times.After vacuum drying for 8 h, the atomically thin and hydrophobic Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were obtained.The atomically thin and hydrophobic Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets prepared with different content of CTAB (0.025, 0.05 and 0.08 g) are labelled as BWO-C1, BWO-C2 and BWO-C3, respectively. For comparison, under the same experimental procedure, the atomically thin and hydrophilic Bi 2 WO 6 nanosheets were prepared with 0.1 mmol of KBr assistant instead of CTAB, which was labelled as BWO-K.And the bulk Bi 2 WO 6 were synthesized without adding CTAB or KBr, which was labelled as BWO. The morphologies and microstructures were obtained by transmission electron microscope (TEM) on Philips-FEI Talos F200S microscope at 200 kV.The scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and the X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were collected by a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector and an EDAX analyzer, respectively.The water contact angle texts of were recorded by a contact angle meter with SL200KS (Kino, USA).Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) were determined by Multimode 8 (Bruker).X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired by a Rigaku D/Max 2550 X-ray diffractometer with Cu K radiation source.The CO 2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 298 K using a Micromeritics TriStar II 3flex automatic specific surface.BET surface areas of samples were obtained at 77 K with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020M instrument.Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) were acquired by VERTEX 70 infrared spectrometer (Bruker).to determine the Bi, W and Br content.Resonance (EPR) signals were measured by Bruker A300 at 80 K to investigate the oxygen vacancies.X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and valence-band X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (VB-XPS) were recorded with Thermo ESCALAB 250 with Al K X-ray.The banding energies of Bi, W, O, and Kr were referred to the C 1s (C sp 3 ) peak at 284.8 eV.(UPS) were measured with a monochromatic He I light source (21.2 eV) and a VG Scienta R4000 analyzer.A bias of -5 V was applied to observe the secondary electron cutoff.Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were collected on a Hitachi U3010.The time-resolved photoluminescence spectra were recorded with Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 with an excitation wavelength of 300 nm, and decay curves were fitted by decay curves of ExpDec1 function. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) were recorded on Thermo Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a liquid nitrogen cooled HgCdTe (MCT) detector.The spectra in absorbance units were acquired with a resolution of 4 cm -1 , using 32 scans.The reaction chamber was equipped with the circulating cooling water system.The irradiation was introduced through a liquid light guide (Au-Light, China) that connects to a 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-HXF300, Au-Light, China).Firstly, high purity CO 2 was continuously passed through a water bubbler to take a mixture of CO 2 and water vapor into the chamber at 8 mL/min for 60 min.After that, the inlet and outlet valves of the reaction chamber was closed.Prior to the light irradiation, the samples were kept in dark at CO 2 and H 2 O atmosphere for 60 min.The sample was under illumination (300 W Xe lamp) for 60 min.The spectra were collected every 10 min, and the light was temporarily blocked during the collection.The temperature of the reactor was kept at 25 C by the cooling water circulation. The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction activity tests of the photocatalysts were carried out in a 250 mL Pyrex glass reactor (PQ256, Beijing Perfectlight, China).Firstly, 30 mg of as-prepared samples and 5 mL of deionized water were added to a watch glass, with an area of 23.75 cm 2 , and then ultrasonic mixing for 10 min.The above suspension was evaporated at 60 C in drying oven to form the uniform film.The design of photocatalytic reactor was shown in Fig. S2.Prior to the light irradiation, the watch glass was put in the reactor, and the air in the system was removed completely by vacuum treatment.Subsequently, a mixture of high purity CO 2 gas and water vapor were purged into the reactor by passing the CO 2 through a water bubbler.The light source was 300 W Xe lamp (CEL-HXF300, Au-Light, China) equipped with AM 1.5.The reaction temperature was kept at 25 C by the circulating cooling water system.The operating reaction pressure during irradiations is under the atmosphere pressure.During each measurement, 1 mL of the mixed gas was periodically withdrawn by a syringe injector and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC7920-TFA, Au-Light, China) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID), thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and nickel catalytic converter.Using Argon as carrier gas and TDX-01 (3 mm 3 m) as chromatographic column, the product including methane, carbon monoxide, and oxygen can be analyzed. Detection accuracy is M t 3 10 -12 g/s (n-hexadecane). The isotope-labeled photocatalytic CO 2 reduction tests were performed by replacing 12 CO 2 with 13 CO 2 gas, while keeping the other reaction conditions unaltered.The obtained mixed gas was analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC Model 6890 N/MS Model 5973, Agilent Technologies).
